$!You must tell DVLA if you have epilepsy.$!

%You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.%

##Car or motorcycle licence

You must [give up your driving licence](/giving-up-your-driving-licence "Giving up your driving licence") if you've had an epileptic attack within the last year. You'll be able to re-apply for your licence once you've been free from attacks for 1 year. 

If you don't want to surrender your licence, or your last attack was over 1 year ago, fill in form FEP1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.


$D
[Download ‘FEP1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 247KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_178630.pdf "Download medical questionnaire"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Bus, coach or lorry licence

You must tell DVLA about any epileptic attacks you've had. Fill in form FEP1V and send it to the address on the form. 

$D
[Download ‘FEP1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 340KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_185934.pdf "Download ‘FEP1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 340KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D



*[DVLA]: Driver Vehicle and Licensing Agency
overview: You must tell DVLA if you have epilepsy - download the correct form to let them know
title: Epilepsy and driving
